Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: SMART Colorimetric Sensor for Airborne Methane Detection
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project will develop phage-based colorimetric sensors to provide cost-effective, low-powered detection and quantification of natural gas. Currently, there is no technology that can reliably detect early natural gas leaks on-site in real-time; existing solutions are either not sensitive enough (handheld infra-red detector) or too bulky (gas chromatography). In the United States alone, almost $3 billion in annual losses results from natural gas leak related disasters ($900 million from lost gas, $2 billion from downstream environmental cost, and $80 million from property damage); the number will only grow with the aging of an estimated three million miles of pipelines in the country. The proposed sensor will offer a selective, yet portable sensing capability for improving natural gas leak detection. Assuming widespread implementation of the phage-based sensor, the anticipated domestic market size is over $60 million initially. In addition, our proposed sensor system has the potential to be designed to rapidly share sensing results through existing telecommunication networks, and thereby reduce the losses due to natural gas leaks. This also has downstream implications in terms of geomapping of methane emission levels, as well as improving pipeline safety.

The intellectual merit of this project is to create a sensor platform that can rapidly develop gas sensor matrices based on engineered M13 bacteriophage (phage). The properties of the sensor, based on highly specific peptide receptors and broadly reactive surface chemistries, are a big advantage over existing colorimetric sensors that require complex synthetic methods in order to incorporate selective elements. This project intends to create a new type of engineered bacteriophage with the capability to display color matrix arrays that can detect and measure components of natural gas. Recognition software that can quickly decipher the phage color change associated with the presence of methane will also be developed through principal component analysis. Finally, initial feasibility tests will be conducted on the phage film to analyze sensor response in isolated operating conditions. The anticipated technical results for this project are the creation of prototype sensor matrix to distinguish methane gas molecules and a corresponding smartphone-based reader and algorithm. These outcomes are vital to the determination of sensor limitations and scalability requirements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview:

This Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project aims to develop a novel colorimetric sensor with the ability to provide cost-effective, low-powered device for the detection and quantification of natural gas. Current natural gas detection technologies in industry suffer from high cost and large size, limiting their use in widespread geographical methane detection. Development of this technology would help reduce gas loss in the environment and boost US competitiveness by reducing reliance on foreign imports of gas.

 

Intellectual Merit:

This Phase I project has successfully designed and developed a proof-of-concept (PoC) prototype of a natural gas sensor for the detection and quantification of natural gas leaks. The proposed sensors were successful in consistently (over 200 tests) differentiating methane and ethane at 100ppm concentrations, thus meeting the requirements for the utility customers. Preliminary study into the phage sensor fabrication also has shown that the sensor is reproducible across multiple manufacturing batches.  That being said, there are also some activities and challenges that remain to be addressed, including: 1) phage sensor consistency and manufacturing tolerances, 2) comprehensive sensor gas profiling, 3) sensor environmental testing, and 4) sensor fabrication scale up. In conclusion, this Phase I project has been carried out successfully. All the major goals have been reached, and going forward, the team aims to address the challenges and problems the technology faces in order to move the project into commercialization.

 

Broader Impact:

The new sensing technology would potentially enable the implementation of an industrial detection grid solution for natural gas leaks, delivering remote and real-time leak monitoring and analytics service to utilities and oil & gas industry. The successful outcomes of this project will contribute to the following areas of public interest:

1. Societal: In the U.S., 670Bcf (its CO2e is more than two times of total CO2 emissions in the U.K.) of gas is leaked from the natural gas industry annually. However, we are still importing more than 3 Tcf of gas in 2015. By better monitoring and recapturing the lost gas, we will be less reliant on foreign gas, thus help U.S. stimulate economic growth and also reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

2. Scientific: A new type of sensor that provide accurate, small, inexpensive, and power-efficient natural gas monitoring with wireless communication capabilities can enable large scale natural gas emission monitoring studies.

3. Educational: Large scale natural gas emission monitoring studies can lead to better understanding of gas emission at scale, thus leading to better emission control and ultimately better environmental outcomes.
